maml:description.maml:para: The Add-AzureADApplicationPolicy cmdlet is not available at this time .
The Add-AzureADApplicationPolicy cmdlet adds an Azure Active Directory application policy.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies how this cmdlet responds to an information event. The acceptable values for this parameter are: * Continue
* Ignore
* Inquire
* SilentlyContinue
* Stop
* Suspend
Specifies a variable in which to store an information event message.
Specifies the ID of the policy.
The ID of the application for which you need to set the policy
Specifies how this cmdlet responds to an information event. The acceptable values for this parameter are: * Continue
* Ignore
* Inquire
* SilentlyContinue
* Stop
* Suspend
Specifies a variable in which to store an information event message.
Specifies the ID of the policy.
The ID of the application for which you need to set the policy

command:example.maml:title: ------------- Example 1: Add an application policy -------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureADApplicationPolicy -ObjectId <object id of application> -RefObjectId <object id of policy>

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds an application policy.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a group to a lifecycle policy
The Add-AzureADMSLifecyclePolicyGroup cmdlet adds a group to a lifecycle policy in Azure Active Directory

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the ID of a group in Azure Active Directory.
Specifies the ID of the lifecycle policy object in Azure Active Directory.
Specifies the ID of a group in Azure Active Directory.
Specifies the ID of the lifecycle policy object in Azure Active Directory.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureADMSLifecyclePolicyGroup -Id "b4c908b0-3595-4add-91b4-c5400b31b57b" -groupId "cffd97bd-6b91-4c4e-b553-6918a320211c"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a group to the lifecycle policy.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a service principal policy.

The Get-AzureADApplicationPolicy cmdlet gets an Azure Active Directory application policy.

maml:description.maml:para: The Get-AzureADApplicationProxyApplication cmdlet retrieves an application configured for Application Proxy in Azure Active Directory.
The Get-AzureADApplicationProxyApplication cmdlet retrieves an application configured for Application Proxy in Azure Active Directory.

maml:Description.maml:para: This is the unique application Id of the application. This can be found using the Get-AzureADApplication command. You can also find this in the Azure Portal by navigating to AAD, Enterprise Applications, All Applications, Select your application, go to the properties tab, and use the ObjectId on that page.

This is the unique application Id of the application. This can be found using the Get-AzureADApplication command. You can also find this in the Azure Portal by navigating to AAD, Enterprise Applications, All Applications, Select your application, go to the properties tab, and use the ObjectId on that page.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: The Get-AzureADApplicationProxyApplicationConnectorGroup cmdlet retrieves the connector group assigned for a specific application.

The Get-AzureADApplicationProxyApplicationConnectorGroup cmdlet retrieves the connector group assigned for the specified application. The application must be configured for Application Proxy in Azure Active Directory (AD).

maml:Description.maml:para: ObjectId is the Id of the application. This can be found using the Get-AzureADApplication command. You can also find this in the Azure Portal by navigating to AAD, Enterprise Applications, All Applications, Select your application, go to the properties tab, and use the ObjectId on that page.

ObjectId is the Id of the application. This can be found using the Get-AzureADApplication command. You can also find this in the Azure Portal by navigating to AAD, Enterprise Applications, All Applications, Select your application, go to the properties tab, and use the ObjectId on that page.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-AzureADApplicationProxyApplicationConnectorGroup -ObjectId 8d6c6684-6f8c-42e2-8914-32ed2adf9ccf
Id Name ConnectorGroupType IsDefault -- ---- ------------------ --------- a39b9095-8dc8-4d3a-86c3-e7b5c3f0fb84 Application Servers applicationProxy False

maml:description.maml:para: The Get-AzureADApplicationProxyApplicationConnector cmdlet a list of all connectors, or if specified, details of a specific connector.
The Get-AzureADApplicationProxyApplicationConnector cmdlet retrieves the details for a given connector. If no connectorId is specified, it retrieves all the connectors assigned to the tenant.

maml:Description.maml:para: If true, return all users. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter

Specifies an oData v3.0 filter statement. This parameter controls which objects are returned. Details on querying with oData can be found here: http://www.odata.org/documentation/odata-version-3-0/odata-version-3-0-core-protocol/#queryingcollections
Specifies the maximum number of records to return.
If true, return all users. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter
The Id of the specific connector. You can find this by running the command without this parameter to get the desired Id, or by going into the portal and viewing connector details.
If true, return all users. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter
Specifies a search string.
If true, return all users. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter

The Id of the specific connector. You can find this by running the command without this parameter to get the desired Id, or by going into the portal and viewing connector details.

Specifies the maximum number of records to return.

maml:description.maml:para: The Get-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorMemberOf command gets the ConnectorGroup that the specified Connector is a member of.

The Get-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorMemberOf command gets the ConnectorGroup that the specified Connector is a member of. If no group has been assigned to the connector, by default it will be in 'Default'.

Id Name ConnectorGroupType IsDefault -- ---- ------------------ --------- a39b9095-8dc8-4d3a-86c3-e7b5c3f0fb84 Application Servers applicationProxy False

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet is used to retrieve a soft deleted directory object from the directory
This cmdlet is used to retrieve a soft deleted directory object from the directory. Note that soft delete for groups is currently only implemented for Unified Groups (a.k.a. Office 365 Groups).

maml:Description.maml:para: The Id of the directory object to retrieve
The Id of the directory object to retrieve

command:example.dev:code: Get-AzureADMSDeletedDirectoryObject -Id 85b5ff1e-0402-400c-9e3c-0f9e965325d1

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to retrieve the deleted directory object with id = 85b5ff1e-0402-400c-9e3c-0f9e965325d1 from the directory

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet is used to retrieve the soft deleted groups in a directory.

This cmdlet is used to retrieve the soft deleted groups in a directory. When a group is deleted it is initially soft deleted and can be recovered during the first 30 days after deletion. After 30 days the group is permanently deleted and can no longer be recovered. Note that soft delete is currently only implemented for Unified Groups (a.k.a. Office 365 Groups).

maml:Description.maml:para: If true, return all group members. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter
Specifies an oData v3.0 filter statement. This parameter controls which objects are returned.
Specifies the maximum number of records to return.
If true, return all group members. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter

Specifies an oData v3.0 filter statement. This parameter controls which objects are returned.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets information about groups in Azure AD.

The Get-AzureADMSGroup cmdlet gets information about groups in Azure Active Directory (Azure AD). To get a group, specify the Id parameter. Specify the SearchString or Filter parameter to find particular groups. If you specify no parameters, this cmdlet gets all groups.

maml:Description.maml:para: If true, return all groups. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter
Specifies an oData v3.0 filter string to match a set of groups.
Specifies the maximum number of records that this cmldet gets. The default value is 100.
If true, return all groups. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter
Specifies the ID of the group that this cmdlet gets.
If true, return all groups. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter
Specifies a search string. This cmdlet gets groups that have DisplayName or Description attributes that match the search string.
If true, return all groups. If false, return the number of objects specified by the Top parameter
Specifies an oData v3.0 filter string to match a set of groups.
Specifies the ID of the group that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies a search string. This cmdlet gets groups that have DisplayName or Description attributes that match the search string.
Specifies the maximum number of records that this cmldet gets. The default value is 100.

maml:description.maml:para: System.Nullable`1[[System.Int32, mscorlib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089]]

maml:alert.maml:para: This cmdlet is currently in Public Preview. While a cmdlet is in Public Preview, we may make changes to the cmdlet which could have unexpected effects. We recommend that you do not use this cmdlet in a production environment.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------ Example 1: Get all groups ------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-AzureADMSGroup
Id : d539a25e-2db2-482a-9dcb-2a0b27fe4f27 Description : OnPremisesSyncEnabled : DisplayName : ADSyncOperators OnPremisesLastSyncDateTime : Mail : MailEnabled : False MailNickname : ADSyncOperators OnPremisesSecurityIdentifier : S-1-5-21-2695029449-1154706203-1063139792-1243 ProxyAddresses : {} SecurityEnabled : True GroupTypes : {} MembershipRule : MembershipRuleProcessingState :
Id : d98ddc78-6e8d-4f0d-8a3f-b923c6ebc14b Description : OnPremisesSyncEnabled : DisplayName : Project Icarus OnPremisesLastSyncDateTime : Mail : MailEnabled : False MailNickname : 60f3d02c-0c6e-41da-bb64-128c73b4d9e6 OnPremisesSecurityIdentifier : ProxyAddresses : {} SecurityEnabled : True GroupTypes : {DynamicMembership} MembershipRule : (user.jobtitle -eq "Sales manager") -or ((user.department -eq "Marketing") -and (user.country -eq "Greece")) MembershipRuleProcessingState : On

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all groups in Azure AD.

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 2: Get a specific group by using an ID --------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-AzureADMSGroup -Id "d98ddc78-6e8d-4f0d-8a3f-b923c6ebc14b"
Id : d98ddc78-6e8d-4f0d-8a3f-b923c6ebc14b Description : OnPremisesSyncEnabled : DisplayName : Project Icarus OnPremisesLastSyncDateTime : Mail : MailEnabled : False MailNickname : 60f3d02c-0c6e-41da-bb64-128c73b4d9e6 OnPremisesSecurityIdentifier : ProxyAddresses : {} SecurityEnabled : True GroupTypes : {DynamicMembership} MembershipRule : (user.jobtitle -eq "Sales manager") -or ((user.department -eq "Marketing") -and (user.country -eq "Greece")) MembershipRuleProcessingState : On

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets information for the group that has the specified ID.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the properties and relationships of a groupLifecyclePolicies object in Azure Active Directory. If you specify no parameters, this cmdlet gets all groupLifecyclePolicies.

The Get-AzureADMSGroupLifecyclePolicy command retrieves the properties and relationships of a groupLifecyclePolicies object in Azure Active Directory. If you specify no parameters, this cmdlet gets all groupLifecyclePolicies.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the ID of a groupLifecyclePolicies object in Azure Active Directory
Specifies the ID of a groupLifecyclePolicies object in Azure Active Directory

maml:description.maml:para: System.Nullable`1[[System.Boolean, mscorlib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089]]

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureADMSGroupLifecyclePolicy

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves the group expiration settings configured for the tenant

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet is used to retrieve the configured identity providers in the directory.

This cmdlet is used to retrieve the identity providers that have been configured in the directory. These identity providers can be used to allow users to sign up for or sign into applications secured by Azure AD B2C.

Configuring an identity provider in your Azure AD tenant also enables future B2B guest scenarios. For example, an organization has resources in Office 365 that needs to be shared with a Gmail user. The Gmail user will use their Google account credentials to authenticate and access the documents.
The current set of identity providers can be Microsoft, Google, Facebook, Amazon, or LinkedIn.

maml:Description.maml:para: The unique identifier for an identity provider.
The unique identifier for an identity provider.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureADMSIdentityProvider

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example retrieves the list of all configured identity providers and their properties.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureADMSIdentityProvider -Id LinkedIn-OAUTH

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example retrieves the properties for the identity provider specified.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an Azure AD group.
The New-AzureADMSGroup cmdlet creates an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) group.

For information about creating dynamic groups, see Using attributes to create advanced rules (https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/active-directory-accessmanagement-groups-with-advanced-rules/).

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a description for the group.
Specifies a display name for the group.
Specifies whether this group is mail enabled.
Currently, you cannot create mail enabled groups in Azure AD.
Specifies a mail nickname for the group. If MailEnabled is $False you must still specify a mail nickname.
Specifies whether the group is security enabled. For security groups, this value must be $True.
Specifies that the group is a dynamic group. To create a dynamic group, specify a value of DynamicMembership.
Specifies the membership rule for a dynamic group.

For more information about the rules that you can use for dynamic groups, see Using attributes to create advanced rules (https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/active-directory-accessmanagement-groups-with-advanced-rules/).
Specifies the rule processing state. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
* "On". Process the group rule.
* "Paused". Stop processing the group rule.
Changing the value of the processing state does not change the members list of the group.
This parameter determines the visibility of the group's content and members list. This parameter can take one of the following values:
* "Public" - Anyone can view the contents of the group
* "Private" - Only members can view the content of the group

* "HiddenMembership" - Only members can view the content of the group and only members, owners, Global/Company Administrator, User Administrator and Helpdesk Administrators can view the members list of the group.
If no value is provided, the default value will be "Public".
Notes:
* This parameter is only valid for groups that have the groupType set to "Unified".
* If a group has this attribute set to "HiddenMembership" it cannot be changed later.

* Anyone can join a group that has this attribute set to "Public". If the attribute is set to Private or HiddenMembership, only owner(s) can add new members to the group and requests to join the group need approval of the owner(s).
Specifies a description for the group.
Specifies a display name for the group.
Specifies whether this group is mail enabled.
Currently, you cannot create mail enabled groups in Azure AD.
Specifies a mail nickname for the group. If MailEnabled is $False you must still specify a mail nickname.
Specifies whether the group is security enabled. For security groups, this value must be $True.
Specifies that the group is a dynamic group. To create a dynamic group, specify a value of DynamicMembership.
Specifies the membership rule for a dynamic group.

For more information about the rules that you can use for dynamic groups, see Using attributes to create advanced rules (https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/active-directory-accessmanagement-groups-with-advanced-rules/).
Specifies the rule processing state. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
* "On". Process the group rule.
* "Paused". Stop processing the group rule.
Changing the value of the processing state does not change the members list of the group.
This parameter determines the visibility of the group's content and members list. This parameter can take one of the following values:
* "Public" - Anyone can view the contents of the group
* "Private" - Only members can view the content of the group

* "HiddenMembership" - Only members can view the content of the group and only members, owners, Global/Company Administrator, User Administrator and Helpdesk Administrators can view the members list of the group.
If no value is provided, the default value will be "Public".
Notes:
* This parameter is only valid for groups that have the groupType set to "Unified".
* If a group has this attribute set to "HiddenMembership" it cannot be changed later.

* Anyone can join a group that has this attribute set to "Public". If the attribute is set to Private or HiddenMembership, only owner(s) can add new members to the group and requests to join the group need approval of the owner(s).

maml:alert.maml:para: This cmdlet is currently in Public Preview. While a cmdlet is in Public Preview, we may make changes to the cmdlet which could have unexpected effects. We recommend that you do not use this cmdlet in a production environment.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1: Create a dynamic group --------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-AzureADMSGroup -DisplayName "Dynamic Group 01" -Description "Dynamic group created from PS" -MailEnabled $False -MailNickName "group" -SecurityEnabled $True -GroupTypes "DynamicMembership" -MembershipRule "(user.department -contains ""Marketing"")" -MembershipRuleProcessingState "On"
Id : 9126185e-25df-4522-a380-7ab697a7241c Description : Dynamic group created from PS OnPremisesSyncEnabled : DisplayName : Dynamic Group 01 OnPremisesLastSyncDateTime : Mail : MailEnabled : False MailNickname : group OnPremisesSecurityIdentifier : ProxyAddresses : {} SecurityEnabled : True GroupTypes : {} MembershipRule : (user.department -eq "Marketing") MembershipRuleProcessingState : Paused

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new dynamic group with the following rule:
`user.department -contains "Marketing"`
The double quotation marks are replaced with single quotation marks.
The processing state is On. This means that all users in the directory that qualify the rule are added as members to the group. Any users that do not qualify are removed from the group.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Using attributes to create advanced rules

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new groupLifecyclePolicy
Creates a new groupLifecyclePolicy in Azure Active Directory

maml:Description.maml:para: Notification emails for groups that have no owners will be sent to these email addresses. List of email addresses separated by a ";".
The number of days a group can exist before it needs to be renewed

This parameter allows the admin to select which office 365 groups the policy will apply to. "None" will create the policy in a disabled state. "All" will apply the policy to every Office 365 group in the tenant. "Selected" will allow the admin to choose specific Office 365 groups that the policy will apply to.
Notification emails for groups that have no owners will be sent to these email addresses. List of email addresses separated by a ";".
The number of days a group can exist before it needs to be renewed

This parameter allows the admin to select which office 365 groups the policy will apply to. "None" will create the policy in a disabled state. "All" will apply the policy to every Office 365 group in the tenant. "Selected" will allow the admin to choose specific Office 365 groups that the policy will apply to.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-AzureADMSGroupLifecyclePolicy -GroupLifetimeInDays 99 -ManagedGroupTypes "Selected" -AlternateNotificationEmails "example@contoso.com"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will create a a new groupLifecyclePolicy setting the group lifetime to 99 days for a selected set of Office 365 groups and send renewal notification emails to groups that have no owners to "example@contoso.com"

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet is used to configure a new identity provider in the directory.

This cmdlet is used to configure an identity provider in the directory. Adding an identity provider will allow users to sign up for or sign into applications secured by Azure AD B2C using the identity provider.

Configuring an identity provider in your Azure AD tenant also enables future B2B guest scenarios. For example, an organization has resources in Office 365 that needs to be shared with a Gmail user. The Gmail user will use their Google account credentials to authenticate and access the documents.
The current set of identity providers can be Microsoft, Google, Facebook, Amazon, or LinkedIn.

maml:Description.maml:para: The client ID for the application. This is the client ID obtained when registering the application with the identity provider.
The client secret for the application. This is the client secret obtained when registering the application with the identity provider.
The display name of the identity provider.
The identity provider type. It must be one of the following values: Microsoft, Google, Facebook, Amazon, or LinkedIn.
The client ID for the application. This is the client ID obtained when registering the application with the identity provider.
The client secret for the application. This is the client secret obtained when registering the application with the identity provider.
The display name of the identity provider.
The identity provider type. It must be one of the following values: Microsoft, Google, Facebook, Amazon, or LinkedIn.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-AzureADMSIdentityProvider -Type LinkedIn -Name LinkedInName -ClientId LinkedInAppClientId -ClientSecret LinkedInAppClientSecret

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds a LinkedIn identity provider.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet is used to invite a new external user to your directory
This cmdlet is used to invite a new external user to your directory.

maml:Description.maml:para: The display name of the user as it will appear in your directory
The Email address to which the invitation is sent
Addition information to specify how the invitation message is sent
The userType of the user being invited. By default, this is Guest. You can invite as Member if you're are company administrator.
The URL to which the invited user is forwarded after accepting the invitation
A Boolean parameter that indicates whether or not an invitation message will be sent to the invited user.
The display name of the user as it will appear in your directory
The Email address to which the invitation is sent
Addition information to specify how the invitation message is sent
The userType of the user being invited. By default, this is Guest. You can invite as Member if you're are company administrator.
The URL to which the invited user is forwarded after accepting the invitation
A Boolean parameter that indicates whether or not an invitation message will be sent to the invited user.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Invite a new external user to your directory ---------
command:example.dev:code: New-AzureADMSInvitation -InvitedUserEmailAddress someexternaluser@externaldomain.com -SendInvitationMessage $True -InviteRedirectUrl "http://myapps.onmicrosoft.com"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Using the cmdlet in this example, an email is sent to the user who's email address is in the -InvitedUserEmailAddress parameter. When the user accepts the invitation, they are forwarded to the url as specified in the -InviteRedirectUrl parameter

maml:description.maml:para: The Remove-AzureADApplicationProxyApplicationConnectorGroup cmdlet sets the connector group assigned for the specified application to 'Default' and removes the current assignment.

If your application is already in the 'Default' group, you will see an error because the application cannot be removed from the 'Default' group unless it is being added to another group. The application must be configured for Application Proxy in Azure Active Directory (AD).

maml:Description.maml:para: The unique application Id of the application. This can be found using the Get-AzureADApplication command. You can also find this in the Azure Portal by navigating to AAD, Enterprise Applications, All Applications, Select your application, go to the properties tab, and use the ObjectId on that page.

The unique application Id of the application. This can be found using the Get-AzureADApplication command. You can also find this in the Azure Portal by navigating to AAD, Enterprise Applications, All Applications, Select your application, go to the properties tab, and use the ObjectId on that page.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Remove-AzureADApplicationProxyApplicationConnectorGroup -ObjectId 59462d3c-a1bc-40a0-9bed-be799357ebce

dev:remarks.maml:para: Example 1: Remove the Connector Group associated with an application, setting the group to 'Default'

maml:description.maml:para: The Remove-AzureADApplicationProxyApplicationConnectorGroup cmdlet deletes an Application Proxy Connector group.
The Remove-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorGroup cmdlet deletes an Application Proxy Connector Group. It can only be used on an empty connector group, with no connectors assigned.

maml:Description.maml:para: The Id of the Connector group to delete. You can find this value by running the Get-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorGroup command.
The Id of the Connector group to delete. You can find this value by running the Get-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorGroup command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Remove-AzureADApplicationProxyApplicationConnectorGroup -ObjectId 59462d3c-a1bc-40a0-9bed-be799357ebce

dev:remarks.maml:para: Example 1: Remove a specific Connector Group

maml:description.maml:para: Renews a group by updating the RenewedDateTime property on a group to the current DateTime.

The Reset-AzureADMSLifeCycleGroup renews a group by updating the RenewedDateTime property on a group to the current DateTime. When a group is renewed, the group expiration is extended by the number of days defined in the policy.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the ID of a group in Azure Active Directory.
Specifies the ID of a group in Azure Active Directory.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Reset-AzureADMSLifeCycleGroup -groupId cffd97bd-6b91-4c4e-b553-6918a320211c

dev:remarks.maml:para: The Reset-AzureADMSLifeCycleGroup renews a specified group by updating the RenewedDateTime property on a group to the current DateTime.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet is used to restore a previously deleted object.

This cmdlet is used to restore a previously deleted object. Currently, only restoring Group and Application objects is supported. When a group or an application is deleted it is initially soft deleted and can be recovered during the first 30 days after deletion. After 30 days the deleted object is permanently deleted and can no longer be recovered. Note that only Unified Groups (a.k.a. Office 365 Groups) can be restored. Security groups cannot be restored.

maml:Description.maml:para: The Id of the directory object to restore
The Id of the directory object to restore

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Restore-AzureADMSDeletedDirectoryObject -Id aa644285-eb75-4389-885e-7233f096984c

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to restore a deleted object with Id aa644285-eb75-4389-885e-7233f096984c

maml:description.maml:para: The Set-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorGroup cmdlet allows you to change the name of a given Application Proxy connector group.
The Set-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorGroup cmdlet allows you to change the name of a given Application Proxy connector group.

maml:Description.maml:para: The unique identifier of the Connector group that will be renamed. You can find the Id using the Get-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorGroup command.
The new name for the Connector group.
The unique identifier of the Connector group that will be renamed. You can find the Id using the Get-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorGroup command.
The new name for the Connector group.

maml:description.maml:para: Microsoft.Open.MSGraph.Model.Name

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureADApplicationProxyConnectorGroup -Id d533d7b1-fd92-49e8-a200-3e7dcf7c2ab5 -Name "Offsite Application Servers"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Example 1: Rename a Connector Group to "Offsite Application Servers"

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a specific group Lifecycle Policy in Azure Active Directory
The Set-AzureADMSGroupLifecyclePolicy command updates a specific group Lifecycle Policy in Azure Active Directory

maml:Description.maml:para: Notification emails for groups that have no owners will be sent to these email addresses. List of email addresses separated by a ";".
The number of days a group can exist before it needs to be renewed
Specifies the ID of a groupLifecyclePolicies object in Azure Active Directory

Allows the admin to select which office 365 groups the policy will apply to. "None" will create the policy in a disabled state. "All" will apply the policy to every Office 365 group in the tenant. "Selected" will allow the admin to choose specific Office 365 groups that the policy will apply to.
Notification emails for groups that have no owners will be sent to these email addresses. List of email addresses separated by a ";".
The number of days a group can exist before it needs to be renewed
Specifies the ID of a groupLifecyclePolicies object in Azure Active Directory

Allows the admin to select which office 365 groups the policy will apply to. "None" will create the policy in a disabled state. "All" will apply the policy to every Office 365 group in the tenant. "Selected" will allow the admin to choose specific Office 365 groups that the policy will apply to.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureADMSGroupLifecyclePolicy -Id "b4c908b0-3595-4add-91b4-c5400b31b57b" -GroupLifetimeInDays 200 -AlternateNotificationEmails "admingroup@contoso.com"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command updates the specified groupLifecyclePolicy in Azure Active Directory

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet is used to update the properties of an existing identity provider configured in the directory.
This cmdlet can be used to update the properties of an existing identity provider. The type of the identity provider cannot be modified.

maml:Description.maml:para: The client ID for the application. This is the client ID obtained when registering the application with the identity provider.
The client secret for the application. This is the client secret obtained when registering the application with the identity provider.
The unique identifier for an identity provider.
The display name of the identity provider.
The client ID for the application. This is the client ID obtained when registering the application with the identity provider.
The client secret for the application. This is the client secret obtained when registering the application with the identity provider.
The unique identifier for an identity provider.
The display name of the identity provider.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureADMSIdentityProvider -Id LinkedIn-OAUTH -ClientId NewClientId -ClientSecret NewClientSecret

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example updates the client ID and client secret for the specified identity provider.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates object settings.
The Set-AzureADObjectSetting cmdlet updates the settings for an object in Azure Active Directory (AD).

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a DirectorySetting object.
Specifies how this cmdlet responds to an information event. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Continue
- Ignore
- Inquire
- SilentlyContinue
- Stop
- Suspend
Specifies an information variable.
Specifies the ID of a settings object.
Specifies the object ID of directory object.
Specifies the target type of a directory object.
Specifies a DirectorySetting object.
Specifies how this cmdlet responds to an information event. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- Continue
- Ignore
- Inquire
- SilentlyContinue
- Stop
- Suspend
Specifies an information variable.
Specifies the ID of a settings object.
Specifies the object ID of directory object.
Specifies the target type of a directory object.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a policy.
The Set-AzureADPolicy cmdlet sets a policy in Azure Active Directory (AD).

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies an alternative ID for the policy.
Specifies the array of stringfied JSON that contains all the rules of the policy. For example -Definition @("{"TokenLifetimePolicy":{"Version":1,"MaxInactiveTime":"20:00:00"}}") .
Specifies the display name.
True if this policy is the organisational default
Specifies the key credentials.
Specifies the type of policy. For token lifetimes, use "TokenLifetimePolicy".
The Id pf the policy for which you want to set values.
Specifies an alternative ID for the policy.
Specifies the array of stringfied JSON that contains all the rules of the policy. For example -Definition @("{"TokenLifetimePolicy":{"Version":1,"MaxInactiveTime":"20:00:00"}}") .
Specifies the display name.
True if this policy is the organisational default
Specifies the key credentials.
Specifies the type of policy. For token lifetimes, use "TokenLifetimePolicy".
The Id pf the policy for which you want to set values.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------ Example 1: Update a policy ------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-AzureADPolicy -ObjectId <object id of policy> -DisplayName <string>

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command updates the specified policy in Azure AD.

maml:description.maml:para: Get detailed sign in summaries
The maximum number of records to return.
The oData v3.0 filter statement. Controls which objects are returned.
The maximum number of records to return.
The oData v3.0 filter statement. Controls which objects are returned.
Get signin summary by last number of days
Number of past days summary will contain. Valid values are 7 and 30
Number of past days summary will contain. Valid values are 7 and 30
Get directory audit logs
The Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs cmdlet gets an Azure Active Directory audit log.
Boolean to express that return all results from the server for the specific query
The maximum number of records to return.
The oData v3.0 filter statement. Controls which objects are returned.
Boolean to express that return all results from the server for the specific query
The maximum number of records to return.
The oData v3.0 filter statement. Controls which objects are returned.

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 1: Get audit logs after a certain date --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs -Filter "activityDateTime gt 2019-03-20"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all audit logs on or after 3/20/2019

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 2: Get audit logs initiated by a user or application --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs -Filter "initiatedBy/user/userPrincipalName eq 'bgates@microsoft.com'" PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs -Filter "initiatedBy/user/displayName eq 'Paul Allen'" PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs -Filter "initiatedBy/app/appId eq 'de8bc8b5-d9f9-48b1-a8ad-b748da725064'" PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs -Filter "initiatedBy/app/displayName eq 'Microsoft'"

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands are different ways to get all audit logs for a certain user or application

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 3: Get audit logs containing a given target resource --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs -Filter "targetResources/any(tr:tr/displayName eq 'Active Directory Example')" PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs -Filter "targetResources/any(tr:tr/type eq 'ServicePrincipal'"

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands show how to get audit logs by target resource display name or type

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 4: Get all audit logs with a given result --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs -Filter "result eq 'success'" PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditDirectoryLogs -Filter "result eq 'failure'" -All $true

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands show how to get audit logs by result

maml:description.maml:para: Get audit logs of signins
The Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs cmdlet gets an Azure Active Directory sign in log.
Boolean to express that return all results from the server for the specific query
The maximum number of records to return.
The oData v3.0 filter statement. Controls which objects are returned.
Boolean to express that return all results from the server for the specific query
The maximum number of records to return.
The oData v3.0 filter statement. Controls which objects are returned.

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 1: Get sign in logs after a certain date --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "createdDateTime gt 2019-03-20"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all sign in logs on or after 3/20/2019

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 2: Get sign in logs for a user or application --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "userPrincipalName eq 'bgates@microsoft.com'" PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "userDisplayName eq 'Paul Allen'" PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "appId eq 'de8bc8b5-d9f9-48b1-a8ad-b748da725064'" PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "appDisplayName eq 'Microsoft'"

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands are different ways to get all sign in logs for a certain user or application

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 3: Get sign in logs from a certain location --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "location/city eq 'Redmond' and location/state eq 'Washington' and location/countryOrRegion eq 'US'"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command shows how to get audit logs by location

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 4: Get all sign in logs with a given status --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "status/errorCode eq 0 -All $true" PS C:\>Get-AzureADAuditSignInLogs -Filter "status/errorCode ne 0"

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands show how to get sign in logs for successes (eq 0) and failures (ne 0)
